cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 255 miles south of Kingston, Jamaica
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to turn northwest Sunday, then north-northwest and move across western Cuba late Monday, emerging into the southeastern Gulf of Mexico Tuesday and tracking north toward the Florida peninsula (eventual bend toward the northeast across the state).
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: central or northern Florida Gulf Coast (between Tampa Bay and the Big Bend)

weather_observation.watch_coast: None in effect for Florida as of Advisory #7
weather_observation.warning_coast: None in effect for Florida as of Advisory #7
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida peninsula, particularly Gulf Coast first then Atlantic side from Cape Canaveral northward including Georgia and the Carolinas
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (sustained ≥34 kt) have a 27 % cumulative chance, peaking late Wednesday–Thursday; gusts could be higher if Ian remains strong while crossing the peninsula.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Depending on the exact exit point, onshore flow could push water 2–4 ft above normal tides along the St. Johns River and adjacent Atlantic beaches.
weather_observation.rainfall: Outer bands could deliver 2–4 inches with locally higher totals (>4 inches) Thursday into Friday, causing flash and urban flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Elevated rip-current risk, possible river rises on the lower St. Johns Basin, and temporary navigation restrictions once gale warnings are hoisted.
